II. ALLEGATION(S)
Violation
Established
DHHS FOM 722-03B – RELATIVE ENGAGEMENT AND PLACEMENT No
If a child must be removed from their home, preference must
be given to placement with a relative. In addition to placement
preference, when a child is removed from their home, federal
and state laws allow for relatives to participate in the case and
have contact with the child. Caseworkers must identify and
provide notice to all adult relatives that a related child is in
foster care. Ongoing efforts to identify, locate, and engage
relatives is an expected part of case planning and
permanency.

INVESTIGATION:
Rule Code & DHHS FOM 722-03B – RELATIVE ENGAGEMENT AND
Section PLACEMENT
Description If a child must be removed from their home, preference must
be given to placement with a relative. In addition to
placement preference, when a child is removed from their
home, federal and state laws allow for relatives to participate
in the case and have contact with the child. Caseworkers
must identify and provide notice to all adult relatives that a
related child is in foster care. Ongoing efforts to identify,
locate, and engage relatives is an expected part of case
planning and permanency.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Agency is not prioritizing or allowing family visits or family placement for
youth in foster care.
Investigation Reporting Source was interviewed by telephone on 09/29/2022.
Other than what was reported in the intake allegation, the reporting
source added that a child should be placed with relatives opposed to
strangers. Reporting Source stated attempts were made to the agency
several times in an attempt to speak with the foster care worker (FCW)
about family visits but there were no contacts made. It was stated that
messages were left but no telephone calls were returned. It was stated
that the agency is not helping with reunification between the family and
Youth A.
Administrator was interviewed by telephone on 09/29/2022 due to
illness. The administrator stated she believes that DHHS is
investigating at least one family member for abuse and neglect, and
that the relatives of Youth A have not been ignored by the assigned
foster care worker. She said the best person to discuss Youth A’s case
with is his assigned foster care worker.
Foster Care Worker (FCW) was interviewed by telephone on
09/29/2022. She stated she was not in the office and was going on
vacation and would not be returning until 10/10/2022. The FCW stated
she received Youth A’s case on 03/29/2019, and that his parental rights
were terminated in December of 2021. She stated currently, Youth A is
acting out sexually with his peers in school and the agency is
attempting to get him stabilized by way of therapy so he can maintain
his current placement. She said she has spoken with Youth A’s great
grand mother regarding visits in the near future.
4

Foster Care Worker was interviewed face-to-face on 10/31/2022.
FCW stated that Youth A is eight years old and has significant mental
health needs and is in once-weekly therapy and is diagnosed with
PTSD, anxiety, depression, impulse control disorder, and suspected
child sexual abuse. He also has an IEP in place and had a tutor last
summer. She said the agency is currently in the process of getting an
SED Waiver in place for Youth A to get additional supports in place for
him as his behavioral concerns have resulted in the foster parents
being hesitant regarding placement. She said there are so many
intricate details to Youth A’s case and the agency is trying to take many
things into consideration, but mostly Youth A's best interest. FCW said
as soon as Youth A is more stable visits with his great grandmother will
begin at the agency office. She said she has been in contact with his
great grandmother, and she is in support of this plan of getting him
stable as not to regress with his behaviors.
FCW stated in March 2022, there were multiple (approximately five)
DHHS complaints received within a span of a week, all of which alleged
that the uncle was living in the home and was sexually abusing Youth
A, that he is a prostitute who is bringing "tricks" into the home and
having sex with them, and that the grandmother and grandfather (who
the agency were told was not living in the home) were abusing drugs
such as Percocet. She said it was also found out that within a span of
2-3 months, there were 17 police calls made to the maternal
grandmother's home where Youth A was residing. FCW said Youth A
missed a significant number of days from school as well. On 3/11/22,
Fostering Futures, DHHS, and MCI determined that it was in Youth A’s
best interest to remove him from the home on an emergent basis due to
the severity of the allegations. FCW stated that there were substantial
findings noted in the DHHS investigation related to these relatives.
FCW stated Youth A was placed in an unrelated foster home in March
2022, and since then, two of the grandmother’s other sons came
forward expressing interest in placement of Youth A; one lives in Texas,
and one who currently lives in Arizona. FCW said she has been in
communication with both of them. She said she explained to them that
moving a foster child across state lines is never an easy process and
that among other things, the agency will have to determine what is in
Youth A's best interest prior to a decision being made. She said when
Youth A was asked about the uncle in Texas, he stated "if they're telling
you I have an uncle in Texas and identified his name, his family is
lying." FCW said she had a phone call scheduled with this uncle on
10/12/2022 to complete a preliminary family assessment. FCW said
historically the uncle in Texas frequently traveled back and forth from
the grandmother’s home and has a room at her house, so if Youth A
4

was placed with this uncle, the agency would be concerned that Youth
A would continue to see his grandmother and uncle. She said she had
a phone call with the uncle in Arizona on 10/13/2022 to complete a
preliminary family assessment for him. FCW said she attempted to call
the uncle several times but was unable to contact him. Her final
attempt was 12/02/2022 and to date he has not returned any of her
phone calls.
FCW said she has been in communication with the maternal great-
grandmother, and she has expressed interest in visits with Youth A.
FCW said she discussed this information with Youth A's LGAL during
an FTM and the decision was made that the agency would be willing to
do an in-person visit with the great grandmother in the near future and
this was expressed to the great- grandmother. FCW said she has had
communication with maternal great-aunt, who seems to be more of a
family 'spokesperson' as she tends to leave voicemails where she is
worked up and complaining that Youth A is not placed with family
members. She said she has returned all of the voicemails left on her
phone. It is noted that the FCW has documentation to support this
information.
Review of MiSACWIS documentation on 10/07/2022, Updated
Service Plan dated 08/28/2022 – 11/25/2022. It was documented that
upon Youth A entering foster care in September 2018, he was placed
with his maternal grandmother. In March 2022, there were several
complaint calls to DHHS which alleged sexual abuse, physical abuse,
improper supervision, and substance abuse in the home. A safety plan
was put into place with the grandmother, however she was found to be
in violation of the safety plan which outlined that she is not allowed to
have her son (who is listed as a perpetrator) living in the home and that
she is not to allow any unsupervised contact between her son and
Youth A. Additional DHHS complaints were received following the
above allegations, so, Youth A was removed from the maternal
grandmother's care on 3/11/22 on an emergent basis and the
placement was found to no longer be in Youth A's best interest. Youth
A was placed in a licensed unrelated foster home on 3/11/22. On
9/15/22, the foster parents signed an Intent to Adopt, indicating that
they are not interested in adopting Youth A. He is currently in the
process of being photo-listed on MARE. In addition, there have been
two out-of-state maternal uncles who have expressed interest in
placement of Youth A, and they are currently being assessed by the
agency.
Other documentation reviewed regarding Youth A’s case include
the following:
4

• Updated Service Plan dated 5/30/2022 – 8/27/2022 detailing
Youth A’s safety plan.
• DHHS report dated 05/06/2022 substantiating the maternal
grandmother and son regarding the allegations made.
• Suspension from school letter dated 06/06/2022 due to
inappropriate behaviors including making derogatory statements
towards female students of what he wants to touch and taste
regarding their body parts.
• Recommendation to deny consent for adoption for the maternal
grandmother dated 10/26/2022.
Analysis No violation is found. There was insufficient information to determine
that the agency was not communicating with Youth A’s family or trying
to keep Youth A from seeing and visiting his relatives. Documentation
reviewed and interviews show the agency has been involved with the
family, although assessed some family members as not in Youth A’s
best interest to have contact with at this time. Additional documentation
shows two uncles have and are being assessed as potential placement
options.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract and policy.
We recommend that the current license status be continued.
01/25/2023
